And then again, this afternoon, Matthew chapter number one, I'll begin reading in verse 18 and I'll read down through verse number 25. And as you are turning there in your Bibles, Matthew chapter number one, you will understand that as you study the word of God, you will discover that one way that God reveals himself to mankind is through his names. We find that in the Old Testament, we find a number of different names that are ascribed to our God that would reveal to us certain attributes, certain characteristics of our God. Why? Because one name is not sufficient to fully describe all that he is or all that he does. And so we find that God has chosen one means by which he has revealed himself to mankind is through his names. I'm thankful that God would be willing to reveal himself to mankind, aren't you? And what a great joy and a great blessing that the God of the universe, the God of heaven, loved us so much that he would not only come to this earth to die for us, to be buried and to rise again, but we understand that he's given us a book, the Bible, and he has revealed himself to us. We understand that the Bible tells us in the Old Testament that the heavens declare the glory of God and the firmament showeth forth his handiwork. We find that in Psalm 19, but the full revelation of God is given to us in the precious word of God, and I'm thankful that God has made himself known. In this record that is before us in Matthew chapter number one, we find that Matthew is providing us with really the conversation, if you will, that takes place between the angel of the Lord and Joseph regarding the birth of the Lord Jesus Christ. In these few verses that record the interaction between Joseph and the angel of the Lord, it's very interesting that we are given two names for the one whose birth we remember at this time of year. The incarnation is the term that we use to describe this wonderful birth of Jesus. It's when God was robed in flesh. That's what the word incarnation means. Notice with me in verse number 18 of Matthew 1, the Bible says this, the birth of Jesus Christ was on this wise, when as his mother Mary was a spouse to Joseph, before they came together, she was found with child of the Holy Ghost. What a great miracle, the virgin birth of the Lord Jesus Christ. Verse 19, then Joseph, her husband, being a just man, not willing to make her a public example, was minded to put her away privily. But while he thought on these things, behold, the angel of the Lord appeared unto him in a dream. Notice this conversation, this instruction that the angel gives to Joseph. The angel says, Joseph, thou son of David, fear not to take unto thee Mary thy wife, for that which is conceived in her is of the Holy Ghost. And she shall bring forth a son, and thou shalt call his name Jesus, for he shall save his people from their sins. Now all this was done that it might be fulfilled, which was spoken of the Lord by the prophet, saying, behold, a virgin shall be with child and shall bring forth a son, and they shall call his name Emmanuel, which being interpreted is God with us. Then Joseph, being raised from sleep, did as the angel of the Lord had bidden him and took unto him his wife, and knew her not till she had brought forth her firstborn son, and he called his name Jesus. In verse number 21, you see the Bible says, and thou shalt call his name Jesus, and then in verse number 23, the second name that is given in this passage of Scripture, it says that they shall call his name Emmanuel. This morning we'll focus on verse number 21, this afternoon we'll focus on verse number 23, but we find that in this text of Scripture, the Bible reveals to us this name Jesus. What a wonderful name it is. We find that the word Jesus literally means Jehovah is salvation. That's what the name Jesus means. And think about the tie that God would be given with that name to the Old Testament Jehovah God, the self-existent one, the one that made himself known to his people Israel. He's now saying, the angel of the Lord says to Joseph, thou shalt call his name Jesus. Jehovah is salvation. We understand the incarnation when God was robed in flesh, the deity of the Lord Jesus Christ, that God came to this earth and he became a man. He never stopped being God. He is the God-man. He's 100% God, 100% man. It's a great truth of God's word. And I'm so thankful that he came. If you were to read the book of Hebrews in the second chapter, you will find that he came and he made himself, took upon himself the form of a man, the seed of Abraham. Why? Why? For he, Jesus, this one that's going to be born, he shall save his people from their sins. How is he going to accomplish that? Well, I'm glad that you asked.
